<!--- intro _ debts/credits/delays explanation --->

## Background
------------------------

Landscapes shape the ecological communities inhabiting them.

Community diversities and population sizes depend on:
- current habitat composition
- history of complex legacy effects from past landscape
<br><br>

> Species response to changes in land cover composition are rarely instantaneous instead subject to gradual extinctions and colonisations through time.

---
<!--- intro _ debts/credits/delays explanation --->

## Extinction debts and Colonization credits
------------------------

<p>Imagine an equilibrium state to which a community will tend to following a disturbance/land-cover change in the landscape.
<br><br/>

If equilibrium > current biodiversity = <b><span style="color:crimson;font-size:130%">extinction debt</span></b> 
<br><br/>

If equilibrium < current biodiversity = <b><span style="color:dodgerblue;font-size:130%">colonisation credit</span></b>

---
<!--- intro _ research aims/hypothesis --->

## Aims
------------------------

Here, we:

> measure the relative contribution of past and present landscapes on the current effective number of species in 2880 US bird communities

.center[&] 

> quantify the extinction debts and colonization credits biodiversity delays to changes in  five land cover types across the contiguous USA.

---
<!--- method _ methods base --->

## Biodiversity data
----------------------

__North America Breeding Bird Survey__

~4000 routes, ~40km long, 50 point count surveys. 

> Routes surveyed both in 2001 and 2016, timepoints chosen due to land cover limitations.

> 960 routes __x__ 3 segments __=__  2880 communities

> Mean species abundance over 3 years around each timepoint used to computed diversity as in the __Effective number of species__ <br> Hill numbers @ q=1, exp(Shannon index).

Triennal raster data, 30m<sup>2</sup> pixel, classified in 15 classes.

>Calculated for each land cover:
- % within buffer in 2001 and 2016
- % point change between timepoints

## Model
------------------------

$$Diversity_{s,t}\sim\ Normal(µ_{s,t},σ)$$

$$µ_{s,t} = \color{#ff70a6}{f(x_{s,t_2};β)}\color{#fca311}{ω(y_{s,t1,t2};γ)}+\color{#ff70a6}{f(x_{s,t_1};β)}\color{#fca311}{(1-ω(y_{s,t_1,t_2};γ))}+\color{#aaf683}{g(z_s;\alpha)}$$
<br>
- <b><span style="color:#ff70a6;font-size:100%">equilibrium component</span></b>

- <b><span style="color:#fca311;font-size:100%">temporal legacy component</span></b>

- <b><span style="color:#aaf683;font-size:100%">static component</span></b>

---
<!--- method _ equilibrium component --->

## <span style="color:#ff70a6">Equilibrium component</span>
------------------------

<br>

$$µ_{s,t} = \color{#ff70a6}{f(x_{s,t_2};β)}ω(y_{s,t1,t2};γ)+\color{#ff70a6}{f(x_{s,t_1};β)}(1-ω(y_{s,t_1,t_2};γ))+g(z_s;\alpha)$$
<br>
Linear and quadratic terms for each land cover + pairwise interactions.

Parameters are estimated once and fixed between _t1_ and _t2_.

It represents the diversity of a given landscape at equilibrium.

---
<!--- method _ delay component --->

## <span style="color:#fca311">Temporal legacy component</span>
------------------------

<br>

$$µ_{s,t} = f(x_{s,t_2};β)\color{#fca311}{ω(y_{s,t1,t2};γ)}+f(x_{s,t_1};β)\color{#fca311}{(1-ω(y_{s,t_1,t_2};γ))}+g(z_s;\alpha)$$
<br>
<!--- Land cover change _y_, at location _s_, per land cover _i_ and directionality _z_ between _t1_ and _t2_. --->

It weights the proportional contribution of the two equilibria, as a function of __magnitude__, __directionality__ and __type__ of land cover change between _t1_ and _t2_.

---
<!--- method _ static additive component --->

## <span style="color:#aaf683">Static component</span>
------------------------

<br>

$$µ_{s,t} = f(x_{s,t_2};β)ω(y_{s,t1,t2};γ)+f(x_{s,t_1};β)(1-ω(y_{s,t_1,t_2};γ))+\color{#aaf683}{g(z_s;\alpha)}$$
<br>
Linear and quadratic effect for temperature in 2016.

Landscape heterogeneity, as effective number of land covers.

Survey time of day & observer level random effect.

---
<!--- method _ recap of modelling base --->

## Model fitting
------------------------

<br>

$$µ_{s,t} = \color{#ff70a6}{f(x_{s,t_2};β)}\color{#fca311}{ω(y_{s,t1,t2};γ)}+\color{#ff70a6}{f(x_{s,t_1};β)}\color{#fca311}{(1-ω(y_{s,t_1,t_2};γ))}+\color{#aaf683}{g(z_s;\alpha)}$$
<br>
Fitted in Bayesian framework with STAN, cmdStanR package.

Priors set with shrinkage properties. 

WAIC-loo driven selection between buffer sizes.

Uncertainty propagation via posterior sampling.

---
<!--- result _ base  --->
## Results
------------------------

1. Distribution of extinction debts and colonization credits across landscapes of the whole contiguous USA.
<br> <br> <br>
2. Change in contribution between past and present landscapes as a function of estimated parameters.
<br> <br> <br>
3. Which land cover change histories result in either debts or credits.

---
<!--- intro _ debts/credits/delays explanation --->

<b><span style="color:crimson;font-size:150%">Extinction debts</span></b> & <b><span style="color:dodgerblue;font-size:150%">Colonization credits</span></b>

-----

<p>The model was able to predict:
- __current__ biodiversity experiencing the past landscape legacy,
- __equilibrium__ biodiversity given the current landscape composition.

<br>
If equilibrium - current biodiversity < 0 = <b><span style="color:crimson;font-size:120%">extinction debt</span></b> 
<br><br/>

If equilibrium - current biodiversity > 0 = <b><span style="color:dodgerblue;font-size:120%">colonisation credit</span></b>

---
<!--- result _ part1 _ text --->

### Distribution of delays across landscapes of the USA
------------------------

Overall, 52% of the contiguous USA territory is expected to lose species and 48% to gain species.
<br> <br>
> <span style="color:crimson;font-size:110%">Extinction debts</span> are concentrated around metropolitan regions.
> <span style="color:dodgerblue;font-size:110%">Colonisation credit</span> are localised in less inhabited areas.

<br>
Biodiversity predictions in 2016 matched the observed data (R<sup>2</sup> = 0.42).

Debts and credits were also compared with more recent survey data.

<!--- result _ part2 _ text --->

### Past and present landscapes contrias a function of estimated parameters.
------------------------

We found that even a 10% conditional increase or decrease in any land cover results in substantial contribution of the past land cover composition. 
<br> <br>
> Stronger legacies from + <span style="color:#a3a3a3 ;">urban</span>, + <span style="color:#e1ad21;">cropland</span>, - <span style="color:#32cd32;">grassland</span>, - <span style="color:#e1ad21;">cropland</span>. 

> Weaker legacies from - <span style="color:#3b7a57;">forest</span> and - <span style="color:#32cd32;">grassland</span>.

<br>
__Type__, __magnitude__ and __directionality__ of land cover change matter.

### Land cover change effect on either debts or credits
------------------------

Landscape modifications have not been homogeneous across the USA.

<br>

> Modelled the magnitude of the predicted debts and credits as a function of changes in land cover.

<br> 

<span style="color:dodgerblue;font-size:110%">Colonisation credit</span> generated by - <span style="color:#32cd32;">grassland</span> and + <span style="color:#ba55d3;">wetland</span> 

<span style="color:crimson;font-size:110%">Extinction debts</span> generated by + <span style="color:#a3a3a3 ;">urban</span>, + <span style="color:#e1ad21;">cropland</span> and - <span style="color:#ba55d3;">wetland</span>

<!--- conclusions --->

## Conclusions
---------   ---------------

Extinction debts and colonization credits are widespread across US avian communities. _talk about urbanisation_

<br>
Biotic responses to landscape change are dynamic and complex and are affected by type, magnitude and directionality.

<br>
__Biodiversity policy targets risk being out-of-date as they are introduced unless past landscapes are considered and debts and credits accounted for.__
